summary: 'i would be curious to meet cicero '
sure they were clean , but romans were n't so good about public health .

text: nacl1on1 asks : my 11-year-old son was absolutely mesmerised by your television series on the romans and decided to teach himself latin ( using an old teach yourself book ) however , the high school to which he will be moving does not teach latin , so how can schoolchildren today go on to university to study the language ?
ie do universities accept students without any qualifications in latin and do all universities still teach it ?
guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 9:13am yes all universities accept people who have no latin to learn the subject at uni .
at cambridge we have a special 4 year course where students learn latin more or less full time in year one , then start greek and the main course in year two .
it 's tough but very stimulating , and you come out with a full classics degree , inc greek and latin
more jokes !
pavlvs asks : what is your favourite joke from the last surviving joke book ?

guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 9:11am a lot to choose from one of my favourites is this : a guy goes up to a eunuch who is walking down the street with a girl , `` is that your wife ? `` .
'people like me dont have wives ' , say the eunuch .
'oh so it 's your daughter then ' says the guy .
chris200 says : forget the book .
it arrived this morning and i know it will be good .
when is your next appearance on television , riding that bike around the ancient sites .
next time hope bbc give you something with a few more gears .
guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 9:08am have just finished making some new programmes , which will be shown next year .
a series on the roman empire and a one off on pompeii .
vastariner said : given the life expectancy of a roman emperor after the 2nd century was measured in months rather than years , why the heck did anyone want the job ?
and how far downhill was rome after the literary heights of the 1st century bc/ad ?
are we like the man looking for his car keys under the street lights because he can not see anywhere else , or was there a genuine downturn in culture , wealth and ability ?
the coinage seems a lot less artistic after awhile guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 9:07am it is very hard to say about roman literature post 1st century ad .
there are some highlights ( i enjoy pliny 's letters , for example ; and tacitus is unbeatable as a historian - both 2nd century ad ) .
but the literary classics of the first cetury do hold the field i agree .
on the emperors : power is an odd thing
bringbackjack said : [ lead pipes ] were used throughout britain until recently , maybe still are in older houses .
advice we were given was to run the tap in the morning to get rid of the water sitting in the lead pipe overnight .
the lead was just the connection from the steel main , to the houses .

guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 9:05am the usual line on roman lead pipes is that the water did not sit in them long enough to be harmful guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 9:14am people used to think it was a reason for decline .
most people now argue that the water did not stand in the lead long enough to have much effect
liviadrusilla asks : i read a description of what roman public baths were really like , and they sounded absolutely filthy .
the water , which was rarely changed , was teeming with body fluids and all manner of nastiness .
certainly a far cry from the pristine image we have of them today !
guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 9:03am exactly !
vastariner asked : i wonder whether any of the [ gladiator ] deaths were fake .
not much point in raising up a gladiator who gets through a dozen fights and is then condemned .
just change the gimmick .
thrasyboulos the terrible thracian gets re-togged as castor the cunning cretan .
guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 9:03am i think they might well have been
groundhogday asks : was rome 's success propelled primarily by hard or soft power ?
guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 9:02am a combination .
conquest is pretty hard power .
but after that rome did not have enough manpower in the provinces to make its power very hard .
it mostly ruled by the collusion and incorporatin of the local provincial elite
swearword asks : who was smarter julius caesar or octavian/augustus ?
guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 9:00am impossible to say for sure .
but the fact that jc was assassinated and oct/aug wasnt is probably indicative !
padd3h asks : i 've always been fascinated with the concept of catiline as a villain , but was there a first catilinarian conspiracy ?
or even a second ?
guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 9:00am i am fairly certain that the first was a figment of roman imagination .
the second is trickier .
something happened .
i dont think and army in etruria was an invention .
but it was probably blown up out of proportion by cicero , in his effort to 'save the state '
julesbywaterlees asks : what has roman history ever done for us ?
i like history but i would like to know what you think of the relevance of a past civilisation to our own and our own future .
guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 8:58am i dont think any past civilsation is directly 'relevant ' .
but it does make us think harder about ourselves and our own assumptions , it is usefully and productively destabilising
caradeuc asks : what would life have been like in roman britain after the last soldiers left in the 5th century .
did town life continue at all ?
guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 8:57am in some form it did , in some places .
one place were you can see some continuity of urban or sub-urban occupation is wroxeter .
but by and large urbanism does collapse .
following her previous answer in which she said she was very excited to work on the only surviving ancient roman joke book , welshexpat22 asked : please tell us a roman joke , mary .
guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 8:55am a man met a friend and said , `` hey i thought you were dead ' .
'no ' said the guy you can see i am alive ' .
'but ' the other replied , ' the man who told me you were dead is much more reliable than you are '

julesbywaterlees asked : at some point in the near future 15 to 100 years our civilisation will reach limits to growth in oil , fossil fuels , resources and we as civilisation may well collapse- did the roman civilisation effectively hit peak roads , peak expansion and effectively ran out of territory to exploit , people to enslave , and trade as a factor in their decline ?
or/and did the 540s c.e .
cool summers and european climate change cause sufficient migration of northern tribes to have a serious impact on rome ?

guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 8:54am the `` decline '' of rome is a big issue , and all kinds of climatic `` natural '' explanations have been proposed ( starting from the great third century ad plague ) .
in my view the migration of northern tribes , which did have an impact , was more political than climatic .

documents.title: there 's more !
text: mary wanted to go back into the comments and kindly answer the questions she could n't get to yesterday .

here are her new answers : dimitri asked : according to michael baigent , richard leigh , and henry lincoln ( holy blood and the holy grail contentious book i know ) , the switch from paganism ( sol invictus ) to christianity took place under emperor constantine , for constantine the cult of sol invictus was , quite simply , expedient .
his primary , indeed obsessive , objective was unity unity in politics , in religion and in territory .
a cult , or state religion , that included all other cults within it obviously abetted this objective .
and it was under the aus of the sol invictus cult that christianity consolidated its position .
could you throw any further light on this shift , and how much christianity is indebted to roman politics ?
guardian contributor marybeard 21 october 2015 8:52am constantine 's `` real '' motivations are very unclear .
but there is no doubt that christianity became very quickly embedded in roman imperial institutions , replacing the `` state religion '' .

documents.title: that 's it for today !
text: thank you to everyone who submitted questions and to mary for joining us and answering so many of them .
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:25pm that 's all from me for now .
but i am going to try to go on later in the week to answer some more , thanks so much for all your great questions and comments , best wishes from mary
magistergill asks : i 'm in a latin as-level class , and my pupils would like to know : why do think classical authors , such as ovid or virgil ( two of our set texts ! )
have transcended time in such a way that they are still relevant now ?
¦ also , do you have any advice for us studying a-level latin and classics ?

guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:24pm i think virgil has stood the test of time precisely because it is not what you would expect of a 'patriotic e ( just think about the last scene what did augustus think when he first heard that ? ) .
advice read a much as you can ( in translation and in latin ) .catullus is a winner in my view .
and enjoy the fact that classics includes archaeology , history literature , language and philosophy i first got into classics through archaeology

documents.title: were brits savages ?
text: jim bartlett asks : i 'm from a generation that was taught that the romans civilised us brits .
we were savages , apparently .
were we liberated by the romans or enslaved by them ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:20pm well it was a bit of both .
the best roman writer on this is tacitus , who wrote a biography of his father in law agricola who was governor of britain .
he had a few sharp things to say about the ambivalence of civilisation and enslavement
phil gollin asks : can you comment on how seriously everyday romans took the gods ?
were they really believed in , or merely part of the society to fit into people 's lives ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:17pm the toughest question in ancient religion .

my guess ( hope this doesnt sound a cop out ) is that there were a very wide range of views ( i compare the image of the nativity how many people think that was what the birth of jesus really looked liek ? )
louise mullineaux asks : i have a practical question .
my 10-year-old daughter really loves greek mythology and is getting into roman and greek history .
it feels like she is developing a genuine love of all things classical and because she knows far more than i do , i 'm wondering how to best support her .
do you have any suggestions for how to encourage her interest and develop it appropriate to her age ?
there is no classics per se on the curriculum at her ( state ) primary , but i wondered if you know of any resources that i could point the school towards or that we could use at home ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:16pm there are things increasingly available .
i dont know where you live , but the british museum has great events and workshops for all ages .
there is a marvellous ltin course for young kids called minimus and all kinds of initiatives to make classical subjects available in all schools .
classics for all is a great charity for this , as is friends of the classics .
if you are near oxford , the east ox classics centre is great
andyf01 asks : why did you decide to specialise in rome , not greece ?
i 've really appreciated some of your views on greece ( eg on thucydides and the peloponnesian war ) .
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:12pm my first interest was ancient greece and i still teach greek history .
i think i got to like the sheer complexity of roman culture ( including the greek speaking bits of it in the east
colonelhathi asks : i am interested to hear your views on the concept of race in roman times .
did the romans view themselves as a superior race ( as opposed to superior civilisation ) ?
one assumes that the romans had contact with black races ( ?
) , but there seem few references .
septimius severus was apparently black , but is of phoenician descent .
who then were the phoenicians ?
before the romans , the iliad and the odyssey have several mentions of the ethiopians .
but who were the ethiopians of the time ?
i have no agenda here , although many do , but i am genuinely interested to know whether there was a roman view of black people as we define them today .
i am also interested in the roman view of themselves : was this race based , or culture based ?

guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:10pm the standard answer ( broadly but not entirely true ) is that rome was nor 'racist ' in the modern sense ( though it certainly had more than a few patches of xenophobia ) .
septimius severus is tricky as in my view ( though we cant be 100 % certain ) he was north african/mediterranean rather than black .
the classic stuff on this is by the black classicist frank snowden
narniagirl asks : i 'm a huge fan of your tv programmes on rome .
what is your second favourite ancient civilisation , after rome ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:07pm you cant really study ancient rome without having one foot in ancient greece , so it has to be that .
lesjulia asks : what government is the best ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:07pm if only we knew
gladiatrix asks : why do you think the senate stood by and did nothing about the physical and cultural destruction of the celtic people of europe by julius caesar , and latterly claudius and nero ?
was it based on material greed eg rome running out of gold until the conquest of gaul - or was it based on ideas of cultural supremacy ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:06pm some of them did worry about it , but lacked the structures to do anything about it .
cato ( not a particularly nice piece of work himself ) suggested arraigning him for war crimes in front of a jury of 'natives '
richard tudor asks : should latin be taught in all state schools ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:05pm i think that it should be available in all schools .
i dont think it should be compuilsory though !

documents.title: how to 'bat away ' sexism
text: boscacci asks : what are your tips for batting away sexism in academia ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:03pm stand one 's ground , and support each other .
we have a long way to go but , that said , in my career enormous strides have been made .
some cause for celebration .
danholloway asks : it 's so fabulous to see you here .
you are one of my true heroes , and responsible for making me feel guilty for the first time for dropping classics after fiveterms and switching to theology and philosophy .
( sorry ! )
it seems that the humanities is being forced into a terrible corner where the only way to justify its existence to students and to governments is to make the economic case for its usefulness .
do you see any positive end to this situation ?
what can those of us in the humanities do to make the case for continued study of humanities subjects ?
we hear a lot of nervous statements that a healthy humanities makes for a better society , but what can we do in the current climate to make that case more forcefully ?
thank you , and keep on being amazing : ) guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 2:02pm spot on .
i think it is very dangerous to go down the economic route ( even if the economic benefits from the humanities are considerable ) .
a bit too much counting how many pounds greek tragedy in the west end brings to the nations coffers .
i usually use the reproductive technologies example does anyone really want new reproductive technologies without a continuing philosophical discussion about the nature of the human .
bowmanthebard asks : did the romans recognise homosexuality ?

we often hear the sus correct view that it 's a recent concept , yet the ancient greeks must have had the concept , because aristophanes categorises people as gay and straight in his speech in plato 's symposium .
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:58pm there were certainly same sex erotics , that 's for sure .
what they seem not to have done very much ( how much is debated like with athens ) is to identify homosexuality as an identifying sexual orientation .
so no 'gay movement '
belgorama asks : i 'll be greedy and try my luck with a third question !
is n't there a danger that in celebrating the achievements of the roman empire we fail to sufficiently appreciate if at all the civilisations that rome conquered ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:57pm i think that the best roman history always tries to see it from both sides .
i have become very careful to avoid using the phrase `` great conqueror '' as it implies you approve ( whenever i see the phrase , i always think in my head `` bloody and brutal conqueror '' )
taxpayingexpat asks : do you think we should pay more attention in our classics and history classes to the hellenised eastern roman empire , instead of focusing so much on the latinised western one ?
and why are we taught so little about the byzantines ?
can we gain insights today by paying more attention to the civilisations that were at or straddled the boundaries between west and east ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:55pm my husband is a byzantinist and i know exactly what he would say .
and i would agree .
we do tend to think of the roman empire too much as a latin cultuyre .
when it was mixed greek and latin .
and in the east the empire didnt `` fall '' till 1453
clstlcat asks : to which roman emperors would you compare bleak , filthy & violent oops , i mean cameron , gideon and ids , and why .
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:54pm oh yes a tricky one there .
i always thought that berlusconi was a bit of a new tiberius ( all those antics in swimming pools ! ) .
i think all these british politicians would like to think of themselves as the down to earth , monet-conscious , provident vespasian not sure that 's how i think of them
holdenandco asks : i 'm reading your book confronting the classics .
if the stories of caligula 's perversions were exaggerated or made up and he was n't as horrible as we were all taught , is there any other reason to remember him and his four-year reign ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:52pm that hits the nail on the head , i think .
the mist important point about imperial history is that it really doesnt seem to have mattered to much to the bigger history of the empire who was on the throne , .
we probably put too much emphasis on individual personality

documents.title: 'i would be curious to meet cicero '
text: samjohnson asks : which roman man would you most like to have known ?

guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:50pm it 's a bit of a cliche but i have worked on cicero so much of my life , that i would be curious to meet him ( caligula/gaius or augustus a close second )
evierose asks : do you think it 's true that modern italians have absolutely nothing in common with ancient romans ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:49pm terribly hard to say .

when i go to naples , however , and o walk down the streets and see workshops open at the bottom of rather grand apartment blocks , i do think : this is what ancient rome must have been like ( a bit ! )
7sisters asks : mary , mary-not so contrary : what tipped roman rulers over the edge ?
had they actually acquired too much power and were unable to deal with it ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:48pm it 's always terribly hard to know the truth about those mad roman rulers .
that is partly because most of the tales were told after their death and were often embroidered to justify assassination .
( `` we had to get rid of him because he was bonkers '' ) that said , the position of ruler of the roman world might have been enough to send most people over the edge .
marmalademog asks : what do you make of roman martial arts , as practised by the gladiators ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:44pm gladiators are a really interesting phenomenon , and there was clearly very big build up of training , specialist equipment etc .
i often suspect though that they might have been more like modern wrestlers than boxers !
zsofia cassidy asks : what advice would you give to your 21-year-old self ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:43pm not to worry so much

documents.title: on ted hughes and ovid ¦
text: mekonj asks : i am enjoying ted hughes ' tales from ovid .
who was ovid ?
how influential was he ?
and how close to the original is hughes ' interpretation ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:42pm ovid was publius ovidius naso , one of the most prolific and in some ways subversive poets of rome at the turn of the common era .
he ended up in exile on the black sea , partly because of a wonderful spoof poem ( ars amatoria ) on how to pull a partner .
hughes 's tales is a wonderful reinterpretation , in some ways the best kind of translation that 'gets ' the spirit of it .
bullfinchinton asks : was the culture of ancient greece a philosophy that was spread out like butter from athens or subcultures that collectively made up for something politically coherent ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:40pm it is very hard to know for sure how ty classical athens was .
most likely not very ty at all .
in some ways it was later greek and roman admiration for classical athens that somehow homogenised it .
the difference that went on beneat the surface are hard to reach but fascinating to reflect on .
rosawatmough asks : i 'm an a-level student applying to study classics at university .
do you think the prevalence of sexual violence towards women in myths and popular literature perpetuated a culture of rape and assault of women in ancient rome ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:38pm that 's a big one ( dissertation size ) .
there certainly is a culture of the acceptance of sexual violence , which is uncomfortable for us .
perhaps the classic example is the rape of the sabines , which was in effect the first roman marriage .
romans did use that myth themselves to reflect on whether all marriage was indeed rape , so were not quite as unreflective as one might fear .
wesfly asks : i 'm currently reading i , claudius .
what 's your opinion of livia , the wife of augustus : a ruthless , devious murderess , or an ambitious lady pursuing the best interests for her family in a male-dominated society ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:35pm i doubt that livia was a retiring flower .
but both ancient writers and modern writers have enjoyed projecting all kinds of fantasies of violent , murderous scheming onto her .
i suspect it is now impossible ( and probably always was ) to sort out what livia really did from what she was supposed to do.woman behind the throne are often convenient scapegoats
tayside asks : apart from sanitation , medicine , education , wine , public order , irrigation , roads , fresh water and public health , what did the romans ever do for us ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:33pm they gave is a way of talking about politics , liberty and the rights of the citizen .
civis roman sum ( i am a roman citizen ) etc .
that 's partly why i start the book with one of the biggest political stand-offs ever between cicero ( in charge of homeland security ) and catiline ( alleged terrorist )

documents.title: is history just chaotic chance events , made sense through hindsight ?
text: meltingman asks : robert musil likened history to a woodworm working its way through a plank , where historians look back at the unplanned tunnel and make it all seem sensible and premeditated .
is history just chaotic chance events with hindsight ?

or is it laziness , as it 's easier to think that , for example , germany just went collectively mad for 12 years from 1933 rather than be weighed down with details ¦ guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:31pm it 's a great image .
i think one of the most difficult balancing acts in writing history is between a desire to make it all make sense on the one hand , and on the other a sense that it is all chaos and accident .
neither is or could be true , but how you balance the two
woostersvalet asks : what is the single most amazing thing you have discovered about ancient rome ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:29pm blimey not sure if this counts as a discovery , but i was very excited to work on the only surviving ancient roman joke book .

documents.title: my desert island book is ¦
text: mgfmskm asks : i 've yet to read any of your books , but i hugely admire you for both being a well-respected and popular historian , and for the ways in which you handle your detractors .
who is your favourite classical author ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:29pm thanks .
i ought to choose a roman book .
but if i had one classical book on my desert island it would be homer 's odyssey .
shitterrorist asks : as a rather mature student , i am currently studying a new roman empire course .
can you say briefly what i should look for as either remarkable or of special interest , post-augustinian period .

guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:28pm the interesting thing for me is not the biographies of individual emperors ( heroes or villains , the empire continues much as usual whoever is on the throne ) .
it bis more how far the system established by augustus gets continued - and fior how long .
take a look at the reign of the third-century elagabalus , a wonderful overturning ( in fantasy ) of the traditional system

documents.title: back to caligula 's time ¦
text: medusa2448 asks : if you could time travel back to a specific time , when would it be and what would you be doing ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:24pm well i hope i wouldnt have to stay long .
but i would love to get a peep inside the roman imperial palace under caligula/gaius ( but i would probably have to be a slave )
frustratedartist asks : what do we know about ancient roman music ?
in your opinion , have there been any convincing attempts to reconstruct it ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:23pm there are some instruments ( or fragments of ) surviving .
flutes and fiddles ( ie lyres ) and drums .
it is fiendishly hard to reconstruct the music .
armand d'angour in oxford is trying to do this with greek music at the moment and roman isnt all that different .
( try googling him i think he has a website on the subject )

documents.title: sure they were clean , but romans were n't so good about public health
text: katewashere asks : i admire you so much , and i am looking forward to your next documentary .
you most definitely belong on tv !
i work in public health and am interested in historical approaches to public health issues .
what was the defining public health achievement of the romans ?
one could argue sanitation and sewerage systems , but were there any other achievements ?
did they take any steps to protect their citizens from the diseases of the day ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:21pm there are certainly some good sanitation schemes .
but generally i fear that the romans were less good than they were cracked up to be at public health .
oner roman doctor sensibly advised people not to go to the public baths if they had an open wound , else they would get gangrene .
a hotbed of germs , we conclude .
esteginette asks : what is the single greatest link between the ancient world and modern one ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:19pm that 's a hard one .
one answer might be 'political organisation and theory '' - democracy tracing back to athens , liberty and civil liberties to rome in particular ,

belgorama asks : what does it say about the differences between greek and roman society that ( almost ) all the literature and theatre still in common currency comes from the greek , not roman , world ?

that greek statues of the male and female form can mesmerise us with their beauty , whereas the roman statues of emperors portrayed as gods seem by comparison to be totally uninspired and leave us cold ?
was rome a cold , militaristic empire with no time or patience for the finer things in life ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:18pm i think it is a bit more complicated .
most of the free standing `` greek '' statues we have are actually made in the roman period and often by romans .
we used to call these 'copies '' of greek masterpieces but they are much more than that.dont underestimate the importance of virgil or ovid or tacitus .
i often claim , thinking it true , that there hasnt been a day since 19 bce when someone in the world has not been reading the aeneid .
i think all ancient cultures were commited to military activity and vistory ( athens as much as rome ) .
the big question is why rome won .
in the book i argue that this was due to an incorporating attitude to citizenship .
i think that people enjoy ancient history because its problem and debates are still part of our own , yet far enough away to feel free to dissect ( well that 's one reason )
tomcasagranda asks : what is the best way , criticism-wise , to approach classics ?
do you embrace the linguistics/semantic approach of jn adams in the latin sexual vocabulary , or the late john griffith 's writing on adverbs , and bruttidius , in juvenal ?
or do you analyse it a la froma zeitlin , amy richlin , john j winkler , from a sexual/textual analysis .
i 'm thinking how radical winkler was , based on foucault .
secondly , what is your opinion of the older books on classical criticism , ie carcopino 's daily life in ancient rome , hdf kitto 's greek tragedy and scullard 's from the gracchi to nero ?
would n't younger students benefit from not touching these archaic , fossilised writings ?
thirdly , is there such a thing as a juvenal delinquent ?

guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:12pm i think that the best critical approach is a combination really ( and in fact the work of winkler and co was based on careful analysis of language ) - but avoiding the 'anal ' .
adams 's work has produced a whole range of theoretical spin offs .
i encourage the young who are starting out to read anything that interest them or fires their imagination .
after that one does need to deconstruct some of the assumptions of the older books though .
i always make sure they know that carcopino was minister of education in vichy fance ( and when you know it shows ! )
too many juvenal delinquents if youn ask me !
lewisdenson asks : academic study is too insular and contained within academic circles , where understanding relies on a background knowledge of the subject .
as someone involved in serious academic study , how do you translate all of that research and specialist knowledge into something that is accessible and tangible , without dumbing it down ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:08pm i think the key is not to under-estimate the audience .
they may not be specialists , but they are not stupid .
so key is to avoid jargon , and very internalised debate constantly to ask what is the important argument here and how can i use the evidence to show that .
to be honest , it is not that different from teaching first year students .
belgorama asks : do you think archaeology has a lot more yet to reveal about the roman occupation of britain ?
guardian contributor marybeard 20 october 2015 1:06pm a lot more in terms of the life and people yes .
some very interesting new work on analysing human remains , with new techniques that can show where the people probably originated .
a lot to contribute to conclusions about mobility in roman world .
and loads of writing coming up from britain in the shape , esp , of letters and curses .
colonelhathi asks : i 'm sure i was taught , in the 1970s , that the order of bathing was : tepidarium , caldarium , frigidarium .
this does n't seem to be the current view .
what do you think ?

documents.title: post your questions for mary beard
text: as a classicist who has embraced the television age and a university professor with 87,000 twitter followers , mary beard has challenged the stuffy image of academia , happily tramping around the former civilisations of europe .
her probing insight and infectious enthusiasm as well as her batting away of sexism have illuminated the present as well as the past .

in addition to a successful academic career , in which she rose through the ranks at cambridge university to become a professor of classics , beard has presented numerous series for the bbc , including examinations of pompeii and caligula .
along the way , she has staunchly defended herself against abuse from online trolls , and against aa gill 's assessment that she really should be kept away from cameras altogether .
beard famously remarked : i am what a 59-year-old woman looks like when she has n't had anything done .
her new book is spqr : a history of ancient rome , which reminds us that the city was not only the seat of modern civilisation , but also bleak , filthy and violent .
on tuesday 20 october , beard joins us for a live webchat from 1pm bst onwards .
post your questions for her in the comments below and she 'll answer as many as possible .
